United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States. Conference at Quebec, 1944
			(1944)

 Substantive preparatory papers, pp. 48-278
			
 PDF (86.4 MB) 



Page 212


THE SECOND QUEBEC CONFERENCE
Department of the Army Files
 The President to the Secretary of War (Stimnson)
 [WASHINGTON,] September 8, 1944.
 MEM:ORANDUM FOR THE SECRETARY OF WAR
 As a result of years of Fascist and Nazi rule and the destruction
resulting from the battles on its soil, I understand that the supply
situation in Italy is critical.
 This situation should be corrected as effectively and as quickly as
possible.
 The War DeDartment should, therefore take immediate action to
make available the additional essential civilian supplies and shipping
necessary to remedy this condition.
 FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT
 E. AUSTRIA AND THE BALKANS
Roosevelt Papers
 Departmment of State Brief/ng Paper
SECRET [Undated.]
 CIVIL AFFAIRS IN THE BALKANS
 American planning for civil affairs in the Balkans is restricted to
Greece, Yugoslavia and Albania on the theory that these will be
liberated territory. No American participation in Rumania, Bulgaria
and Hungary is contemplated in presellt plans, unless it is found that
these countries have surpluses of foodstuffs or products useful in the
war, for the handling of which American perso-nnel in Allied missions
might be desirable.
 The, U.S. Army has set up, Lunder autlorization of the President,
a combined Anglo-American Military Headquarters for relief and
rehabilitation in Greece, Albania and Yugoslavia, the American )ar-
ticipation being limited to sixty-three, all officers, while British per-
sonnel will number several thousand. On our initiative an agreement
has been made between UNRPIA and the military authorities whereby
UNRRA will serve as the agency of the combined military head-
quarters for the distribution of the supplies during the military pe-
riod.2 In view of the American origin of the bulk of the supplies and
1 Annex 7 to Hull's memorandumi to Roosevelt dated September 6, 1944, which
was sent to the White House under cover of a further memorandum of Septem-
ber 8. See ante, p. 120.
 "For the text of the agreement referred to, signed at Cairo, April
3. 1944, see
George Woodbridge, UNRRA: The History of the United Nations Relief and
Rehabilitation Administration (New York: Columbia University Press, 1950),
Vol. InI, pp. 210-211.
